Biography: I'm a software engineer that is passionate about developing solutions. If there's a problem there's an opportunity. I love travelling the world and doing hiking here in Colombia. ¬°I will not rest until my two scratchable maps are 100% complete!
Submission: Talk (40 minutes including Q&A) /  Charla (40 minutos incluyendo preguntas)
Title: Building a Scalable Food Delivery Service Using ElasticSearch Geo Queries
Description:
**** Submission description ****

With the rise of food delivery services in Colombia, it‚Äôs a good time to discuss the technical aspects involved in their operation. How do they manage to provide a list of the nearest available restaurants to your location within seconds? How do they manage to handle thousands of request and still display updated information taking into account schedules? With ElasticSearch Geo Queries we can set up a fully functional service that can scale to satisfy the growing demand of users that want their lunch delivered to their home in a reasonable amount of time.

**** Why are you the right person to give this talk? ****
(Answering here because the field has a weird bug regarding punctuation)

I worked at Domicilios.com for over two years. I started there in 2016 as a backend engineer for the company's internal tools, but given the increased demand of users and the inability of our stack to provide reasonable response times, I was moved to the core team. In this new phase we were responsible of providing scalable solutions to handle the incredible expansion the market was suffering back in 2017. 

We started optimizing the API, both in code and infrastructure but it was not enough: an increase of order cancellations and bad reviews in our app and in social networks told us that our efforts were not sufficient. That's when we decided to move our geolocation service from code and traditional databases to ElasticSearch. We did several spikes with different geolocation technologies and we loved the Elastic solution. We spent months trying to setup the right architecture and coordinating data between our main database and ES to avoid displaying outdated information. 

But then the results came. We managed to decrease the load time in our application by several seconds. Now our users were able to locate within a second or two their favorite restaurants and place and order without the hassle of waiting for the information to load.

Biography:
Prior to Elastic, Flavio worked at Red Hat (and OpenStack) for over 6 years. During that time, he contributed to storage, messaging, and deployment services. He was an elected member of the OpenStack's technical committee for 3 years. He helped to grow the OpenStack team at Red Hat and worked on integrating OpenStack and Kubernetes.

Outside work Flavio likes to surf, run, travel, hang around with family and friends and whatever seems interesting.
Submission: Talk (40 minutes including Q&A) /  Charla (40 minutos incluyendo preguntas)
Title: Inheriting code, and I don't mean classes
Description:
One of the hardest things to do for developers, especially freelancers, is to inherit someone else‚Äôs code. Let alone doing it when the original author is not around anymore. Whether it‚Äôs an open source project, an internal project, or some small web page that your best friend asked you to fix. Code that has not been written by us is always ugly, not performant, and broken.

How does one go about inheriting other people‚Äôs code? How do you wrap your head around the (wrong?) ideas, the (flawed?) logic, and the (lack of?) taste of other developers(?)? How can you take such code, make it yours, make it better, and sprinkle your fairy dust all over it? Also, do you really really really write better code? ;)

Join me while I share some of my experiences on this topic, some strategies to inherit old code without (totally) going mental, and how to rant about it without looking like a douchebag.

Biography: Ben Dechrai is a technologist with a strong focus on security and privacy. He enjoys helping developers find the joy of problem solving and experimentation, and can be found on Twitter and Instagram at @bendechrai.
Submission: Talk (40 minutes including Q&A) /  Charla (40 minutos incluyendo preguntas)
Title: My voice is my passport. Verify me?
Description:
Security is hard. Using the same password for everything is easy.

Over the years, we've made it easier for users to do the right thing, from email-based verification to one-time passwords via email and security tokens. But nearly all these solutions require you to have your mobile phone, or security device with you. And if you're overseas, you might have additional problems.

Let's look at mechanisms for biometric authentication with web applications. There are a few out here, and this talk will help you understand the options and implementation, together with a live demo.

Biometric security? Because you rarely leave your face and voice at home!

Title: Programaci√≥n en paralelo con Python: s√°cale jugo a los n√∫cleos de tu computadora
Description:
Ahora m√°s que nunca, personas de distintas √°reas del conocimiento han aprendido a programar. Debido a su formaci√≥n no t√©cnica, los conceptos b√°sicos de programaci√≥n en paralelo son desconocidos y estamos perdiendo tiempo precioso de nuestras vidas al programar tareas largas de manera secuencial.

En esta charla cubriremos los conceptos b√°sicos de programaci√≥n en paralelo con Python y mostraremos lo f√°cil que es implementarlo en Python. Tambi√©n aclararemos ciertos mitos como que en Python no hay paralelismo real e introduciremos distintas herramientas para usar f√°cilmente programaci√≥n en paralelo con Python. Se explicar√°n ciertas consideraciones que debemos tener en cuenta para crear programas que hagan procesamiento en paralelo. Finalmente introduciremos unos casos de estudio, por ejemplo, de c√≥mo aplicar programaci√≥n en paralelo para acelerar la evaluaci√≥n de modelos de Machine Learning.

Outline

Introducci√≥n (5 minutos)
* Problema: Todos tenemos acceso a distintos n√∫cleos pero escribimos c√≥digo que solamente utiliza un n√∫cleo.
* Ejemplos de tareas que podemos hacer en paralelo 
* Demostraci√≥n en vivo de c√≥mo se usa en nuestra vida diaria: ejecutar una operaci√≥n de IO que bloquea una interfaz gr√°fica VS. una que utiliza hilos cuya interfaz no se bloquea.
Hilos y procesos (10 minutos)
* Definici√≥n de hilos
* Definici√≥n de procesos
* Diferencia entre hilos y procesos 
* El GIL en Python 
* Cu√°ndo usar hilos y cu√°ndo usar procesos
* Sincronizaci√≥n 
* Memoria compartida
Paralelismo en Python (12 minutos)
* Hilos (M√≥dulo threading)
* Procesos (M√≥dulo multiprocessing)
* Pools y workers
* Librer√≠a joblib
Casos de estudio (7 minutos)
* Procesando XML en paralelo
* Acelerando classifier chain en scikit-learn
* Ejecutar cross validation en paralelo
Consideraciones (3 minutos)
* Paralelismo introduce complejidad al sistema 
* Sincronizaci√≥n y tareas de corta duraci√≥n pueden resultar en menor rendimiento
* Ciertos problemas no escalan linealmente
* No todos los problemas se pueden dividir f√°cilmente 
* Frameworks como Spark y dask te dan paralelismo autom√°tico, dependiendo de la tarea.
Preguntas (3 minutos)

NB: En caso de ser necesario, la charla y las diapositivas pueden ser impartidas en ingl√©s.

Biography:

Title: Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away
Description:
Could you imagine an internet where all links stopped working after 4 years? All the old blogs from the 90‚Äôs‚Ä¶ gone, all your hot takes on Twitter‚Ä¶ gone, all the news and reporting‚Ä¶ gone.

Some of that decay is good, no one wants the entire internet to be preserved for eternity, but most of that decay leads to great content disappearing forever, and future generations being deprived of access to the most important medium for knowledge in the last half century. If no one worked on preserving that information, the human race would be facing a loss of knowledge many times greater than the burning of the Library of Alexandria.

Luckily organizations like Archive.org and the Internet Preservation Consortium work tirelessly every day to save what they can. But archiving doesn‚Äôt have to be exclusive to big organizations, we can all play a part by archiving the stuff that matters to us locally. Learn about the internet archiving community, the tools of the trade, and how to save content you care about in this talk!

Title: Perceiving Python Programming Paradigms
Description:
The soaring popularity of Python and its assorted applications can be attributed to its simplicity and flexibility. In this talk, I will review the modern bloom & dominance of Python and discuss four major coding styles often used: Imperative, Procedural, Functional, and Object-Oriented. I will go over the fundamentals of each programming paradigm and discuss their positives, limitations and use cases especially in Python setting along-with a very simple hands-on example to illustrate how one routine can be coded in a different style. The talk will conclude with some pointers on how to choose a coding style for a given situation to make the code more readable, testable and coherent.

This talk aims to introduce different programming styles of Python and encourage Pythonistas to reflect on the implications of each corresponding to their domain viz. data visualisation, machine learning, functional programming, or embedded systems, web development. By better understanding these styles attendees will be empowered to design efficient solutions.


Outline of the proposed talk

Introduction
The rise of Python and its many applications: Reason for its bloom & dominance
Reflecting on the simplicity and flexibility providing comfort and independence

Overview of programming styles with positives & limitations in each
Imperative Programming: Sequential, Direct change to program state, Data structure manipulation, Harder debugging, Limited abstraction, Complex semantics
Procedural Programming: Sequential, Iterative, Modularized, Tasks‚Äô function calling, Inefficient hardware usage especially for complex problems
Functional Programming: Stateless functions, Immutable data, Independent of order of execution, More modularity, Useful for - Recursion, Lambda Functions, Parallel Processing
Object-oriented Programming: Object manipulation via methods only, Code reusability, Limited support by Python (currently)

One example coded in different programming styles for illustration
Task definition, say average of a list of numbers
Code in different styles: Imperative, Procedural, Functional, Object-oriented
Usage of lambda functions, class creation, method creation, etc.
Discussing speed, efficiency, reusability, simplicity of each style

Conclusion & Takeaways
Pointers on how to select a programming paradigm based on the application
Discussing pros and cons of combining, interleaving multiple styles
Some personal anecdotes, recommendations for different use cases
Tags: Aritificial intelligence, Data Sciece, Core Python, Machine Learning

Title: Breaking the Enigma: what if Turing had Python?
Description: In this talk I want to bring back all the cryptographic work done during the World War II regarding the deciphering of the nazi communication system. In particular, I will present a python re-creation of the Enigma machine used to encrypt messages during the war, but most importantly I will present a historically accurate python simulator of the Bombe machine used to crack this cipher. I want to present, with our current technology and architecture, how did the researchers at Bletchley Park engineered an electro-mechanical device, key to end the war. And how by doing that, they contribute to setting the bases for the first computers. I am going to present the technical challenges and the human efforts involved in breaking a code such as Enigma, as well as the key flaws that doomed it. Finally, I will try to obtain a replica of the Enigma machine in order for the audience to experiment the cipher process and elements first hand.

Title: Time Series Forecasting using Machine Learning
Description:
On this talk I will introduce the time series forecasting problem, the traditional methods as well as recent ML approaches discussing important steps such as target value transformation, commonly used predictors as well as hyper-parameter search.

Description: When mentioning Time Series Forecasting what comes to mind are autoregressive models or exponential smoothing techniques using a dependent variable and the time dimension. Although those techniques work well in some domains, in others like retail, e-commerce, logistic and pricing, time series can be influenced by external factors that are hard to model using these traditional methods.

When posing time series forecasting as a regression problem, one can use machine learning techniques like linear regression and support vector machines as well as more advanced models such as neural nets and boosted trees to perform the forecast. The main challenge here is not related to the particular machine learning technique but to the data preparation and feature engineering necessary to create powerful predictors.

The talk is divided in three sections: in the first section I will briefly describe time series and their applications; common evaluation metrics, the models used traditionally to work with them and the limitations they bring. In the second I will focus on modeling, describing some machine learning methodologies, useful predictors and transformations that improve their predictive power. Finally I will combine the aforementioned concepts in small code samples using publicly available datasets to show how to apply some of these techniques using Python.The libraries used for include Pandas, Scikit-Learn and Catboost.

This talk assumes you are familiar with basic Machine Learning concepts. Previous knowledge of time series forecasting is not necessary but beneficial. Knowledge of the Python stack for data processing (numpy, scikit-learn, pandas, etc.) is recommended.
Tags: Aritificial intelligence, Data Sciece, Machine Learning

Title: Did you know it‚Äôs possible to avoid bugs only by using types? Meet ‚ÄúType Driven Development‚Äù, a strong approach used to get rid of common bugs in the code and it can be used in Python
Description:
Did you know there is another TDD? Type Driven Development can increase the performance, accuracy, and readability of your code by taking advantage of the Python‚Äôs type system. A strongly typed language has a huge incidence in software design and quality, and being Python a dynamic and strongly-typed language, we can take advantage of the type system to implement an early bug-detection mechanism by using the support for type hints. 
In this talk, we are going to discuss the benefits of using Python‚Äôs type annotations, how to use them on our daily basis and the tooling available to perform static check analysis. I‚Äôm going to share some code samples based on real-life scenarios where some bugs can be detected/prevented. We‚Äôll see why specific unit tests are not necessary by using this practice.
Tags: Core Python, Software Design / Best Practices

Title: Enhancing Data Privacy through Federated (Machine) Learning
Description:
"Standard machine learning approaches require centralizing the training data in a central data store. Now for models trained from user interaction with mobile and IoT devices, there is an additional approach: Federated Learning. 

This enables mobile devices to collaboratively learn a shared prediction model while keeping all the training data on device, decoupling the ability to do Machine Learning from the need to store the data in the cloud. This goes beyond the use of local models that make predictions on mobile devices by bringing model training to the device as well. Federated Learning thus allows for smarter models, lower latency, and less power consumption, all while ensuring privacy".

This talk aims at explaining the fundamentals behind implementing Federated Learning capabilities, along with presenting some Python tools which serve to this purpose.
Tags: Aritificial intelligence, Data Sciece, IoT, Machine Learning, Security, DataOps, Privacy

Title: Antes mi servicio se demoraba 5 seg y ahora 300 miliseg, veamos que es profiling en diferentes capas, Base de datos, aplicaci√≥n, cache, mobile, para llevar a tus aplicaciones a otro nivel de velocidad.
Description:
Esta charla es para un p√∫blico intermedio-avanzado.

Se realizar√° en dos secciones (Optimizaciones y posibles degradaciones) y muestra como se realiza profiling de aplicaciones en ambientes de desarrollo y luego como se puede realizar optimizaciones en producci√≥n, reduciendo tiempos de respuesta en diferentes capas (Base de datos, aplicaci√≥n, cache, contenido est√°tico) 
En cada capa se mostrar√° un ejemplo normal de uso y el tiempo de consumo en respuesta en un ambiente de producci√≥n y luego con la optimizaci√≥n como se encuentran cambios y se optimiza reduciendo tiempo, memoria o CPU de uso..

Luego seguir√° una secci√≥n de como identificar, encontrar y monitorear degradamientos de sistemas en producci√≥n y por que es tan importante el profiling, ahorrando dinero en sistemas de producci√≥n.

Se usar√° como base para el taller flask y django, y se abordar√° otros frameworks como Sanic.

He is also fan of deep learning computer vision, data mining and econophysics. Moreover, he enjoys playing table tennis and acting.
Submission: Talk (40 minutes including Q&A) /  Charla (40 minutos incluyendo preguntas)
Title: Movie Genre Classification Using Deep Multimodal Neural Networks
Description: The classification of films according to their genre is of main interest for various multimedia companies (Netflix, YouTube, etc.). In order to perform the classification it is possible to analyze two types of data: The images of the posters and the text of the synopsis. Currently, both types of data are easily understood by a human being, but for a machine it is a challenge to analyze and correlate them. Additionally, the problem of the genre classification of films is a challenge in the Machine Learning area because it is a multi-class problem and at the same time multi-genre, that is, the same film can belong to several genres simultaneously. This talk will explain how to make use of deep learning to automate the classification of films thanks to the interpretation of text and images. In detail, the operation and use of convolutional neural networks and transfer learning for image processing on posters will be explained. And, on the other hand, recurrent neural networks will be explained in combination with unsupervised methods (Word2Vec) for the pre-processing and training of the synopsis classification algorithms. Finally, we will talk about how to add the information of both types of data - images and text - in a multi modal neural network to find the genres to which a movie belongs.
Tags: Aritificial intelligence, Data Sciece, Machine Learning

Title: Comprension de la musica con Python, una mirada desde la Fisica y la Matematica
Description:
La M√∫sica es para todos, es una manifestaci√≥n de la naturaleza.
En esta charla entenderemos por que los sonidos son agradables o desagradables, y con el conocimiento b√°sico todos podemos crear melod√≠as y acordes  comprendiendo como funciona la armon√≠a musical b√°sica desde la f√≠sica y las matem√°ticas.
Utilizaremos Python para demostrar  y visualizar como es la naturaleza de las ondas del sonido, la relaci√≥n entre diferentes notas y como se unen para crear la Armon√≠a Musical.

He trabajado con diferentes tecnolog√≠as a lo largo de mi experiencia profesional, comenzando con PHP, pasando al mundo Javascript (Node JS / React ), continuando con el mundo Java (Android), programaci√≥n funcional en Scala y finalmente Python, lenguaje que le he dedicado el 100 % de mi tiempo durante los √∫ltimos cuatro a√±os. A parte de mi pasi√≥n por el software siempre me he caracterizado por ser una persona curiosa en diferentes t√≥picos del saber realizando estudios en econom√≠a, finanzas, inversiones y liderazgo. Mi inter√©s por dar esta charla es porque uno de mis prop√≥sitos en mi vida es impactar la vida de otras personas, y lo quiero materializar haciendo las cosas que m√°s me gustan y en las que tengo mas experiencia, asi que quiero compartir mi conocimiento con la mayor cantidad de personas que pueda y comenzar a aportar en desarrollos open source. Aportando as√≠ mi grano de arena en la transformaci√≥n tecnol√≥gica que est√° ocurriendo en Colombia y en latinoam√©rica. Amo los animales y apoyo fundaciones que se encargan de los perros y gatos callejeros del municipio de Bello, especialmente la fundaci√≥n Alma Animal  (https://almanimalmed.wixsite.com/almanimalmed). Mi prop√≥sito es crear mi propia fundaci√≥n en la ciudad de Medell√≠n que pueda sacar la mayor cantidad de J√≥venes de la pobreza y de la violencia, viendo en la tecnolog√≠a la esperanza para abrir nuevas posibilidades en sus vidas.

Title: Como migrar mi proyecto de Python 2 a Python 3
Description:
El 1 de Enero del 2020 es la fecha oficial del final del soporte de Python 2. Si tienes proyectos desarrollados en Python 2, si quieres mejorar tus conocimientos en Python 3 o si te interesa liderar proyectos de transformaci√≥n tecnol√≥gica en la compa√±√≠a o en los proyectos donde haces parte, esta charla es la indicada para ti. Hablaremos a cerca de las estrategias que en Lendingfront nos permitieron enfrentar los retos t√©cnicos y procedimentales que hacen posible esta migraci√≥n como te las describo a continuaci√≥n:
1. Identificando y Migrando librer√≠as sin soporte en Python 3 en mi proyecto (caniusepython3, pipcheck, suds)
2. Python 3.6, Python 3.7 o Python 3.8 ? Cual es la versi√≥n m√°s adecuada ? Pros y Contras.
3. Desarrollando tu c√≥digo compatible con Python 2 y Python 3 al mismo tiempo (six, contexter, python-modernize, python-future)
4. Creando pruebas automatizadas usando Tox.
5. Automatizando la transformaci√≥n de tu c√≥digo a Python 3 (2to3)
6. Aprendiendo las diferencias m√°s importantes entre Python 2 y Python 3 en tiempo record (Excepciones, Divisi√≥n de enteros, Enteros Largos, Manejo de strings, Diccionarios)
7. Caso de estudio: Migrando un servicio de pagos  que maneja cientos de transacciones todos los d√≠as en producci√≥n (Identificando puntos m√°s cr√≠ticos con el manejo de Integers, Floats y Enteros Largos)
8. Culturizando tu equipo de desarrollo con Code Review + Talks + Pylint + Travis.
9. Coordinando con el equipo de QA como estrategia para  garantizar la estabilidad de tu proyecto en producci√≥n.
10. Llevando tu migraci√≥n de Python 3 de manera gradual a producci√≥n  (Contenedores, Servicios aislados).

Biography:

Submission: Talk (40 minutes including Q&A) /  Charla (40 minutos incluyendo preguntas)
Title: Procesamiento de datos en sistemas distribuidos con python
Description:
Antecedentes
Hoy en dia es muy com√∫n escuchar que python se usa en el an√°lisis de datos, lo cual es cierto, lo que casi nunca nos detenemos a pensar es ¬øDe donde vienen esos datos?, ¬øC√≥mo se generaron?, ¬øC√≥mo se guardan?, ¬øC√≥mo se actualizan y con qu√© frecuencia?, etc.
En esta charla explicar√© estos puntos y nos enfocaremos en un caso muy espec√≠fico (Real-Time Data Sources) que cada vez m√°s han ido adoptando diferentes industrias en la era de la informaci√≥n .

Intrducci√≥n - 5 min
    Hablo acerca de c√≥mo surgi√≥ la necesidad de implementar una soluci√≥n custom y los problemas de los productos del mercado 

Panorama general - 5 min
    Explicaci√≥n de los componentes principales de la arquitectura del sistema.

Procesamiento de datos - 15 min
    Es la parte principal de la charla y mostrar√© como podemos utilizar python (con ayuda de la biblioteca de Faust) para sistemas cr√≠ticos que requieren procesamiento a gran velocidad de grandes vol√∫menes de informaci√≥n, desmintiendo el mito de que python es muy lento para usarlo en este tipo de sistemas.

Conclusiones - 5 min 
    Benchmarks realizados y consideraciones.

Biography:

Title: Hablemos de voz
Description:
Desde que creamos los ordenadores nos hemos preguntado si ser√°n inteligentes, Alan Turing en la prueba que lleva su nombre describi√≥ inteligencia como la capacidad de mantener una "conversaci√≥n" con un agente y que sea indiferenciado con un humano. ¬°Y la mayor√≠a de seres humanos nos comunicamos hablando!

Desde los a√±os 60, en los laboratorios de IBM y AT&T prototipos capaces de reconocer palabras han sido desarrollados y ochenta a√±os despu√©s, los reconocedores autom√°ticos de voz hacen parte de nuestra vida: Google Assistant, Siri, Alexa, Cortana y muchos otros.

En esta charla vamos a hablar de voz, desde lo te√≥rico hasta lo pr√°ctico, entendiendo como esta se√±al de audio es muy caracter√≠stica dependiendo de nuestro cuerpo y nuestro idioma, como extraemos caracter√≠sticas y generamos modelos para predecir y producir voz, desde casi cero y con Python puro y duro
Tags: Aritificial intelligence, Machine Learning, Scientific Computing, Speech Processing

Biography:

Title: Debugging: A Senior's Skill
Description:
Have you ever find yourself trying to discover what's the bug in the codebase you're working for, running and restarting the application with print statements all over the place? Perhaps you've realized how difficult and time costing it is, and in some situations, very frustrating.

Most Senior developers have some things in common, and one of them is their ability to debug problems the proper way (Using the correct tools).

If you've ever found like debuggers are gruesome tools that you should avoid at all cost and stick to your print statements, as I did some time, please come to my talk and maybe I'll help you out to change this mindset and give you the motivation to become a master debugger.

Talk Outline:
1. How people use to debug problems (5 mins)
2. Why should you use a debugger (5 mins)
3. Introduction to ipdb (10 mins)
4. Real Troubleshooting using ipdb (8 mins)
5. Conclusions, Final Thoughts (2 mins)
6. Q & A (10 mins)

Title: The road so far on building a web platform for drones
Description:
Drones extend our vision of the world and allow us to see, sense and feel the environment in a new level of awesomeness.
Imagine you are a scientist who needs to share the flight path and sensor readings of a drone experiment.
Imagine you are a kid who can watch a scientist planning a flight path and see how the drone flies.
Come to my talk to learn how I've built a web interface using Python to manage, examine, and share drone experiences, and get a glimpse of the world from above!

Biography:

Siempre me he sentido apasionado por aprender sobre temas como la inteligencia artificial, la seguridad de la informaci√≥n, el procesamiento de lenguaje natural, los videojuegos, entre otros.

Title: Ocultando datos en datos
Description:
Cuando se habla de comunicaciones secretas en la era digital se suele pensar primero en comunicaciones cifradas, criptograf√≠a. Sin embargo existen otras t√©cnicas que pretenden mantener la confidencialidad de los mensajes, incluso a plena vista. En esta charla se introduce el concepto de esteganograf√≠a y sus diversas formas y usos en el entorno digital al igual que algunas librer√≠as y ejemplos en Python para tratar archivos de im√°genes y sonido con el fin de embeber y extraer mensajes de los mismos.

En palabras simples, la esteganograf√≠a es es arte de ocultar datos en otros datos. Hoy por hoy todo es informaci√≥n, es decir, datos; lo que implica que virtualmente es posible embeber mensajes ocultos casi en cualquier parte siempre y cuando existan unas reglas de comunicaci√≥n definidas entre el emisor y el receptor, es decir, un lenguaje.

Al terminar la charla, la audiencia podr√° definir qu√© es esteganograf√≠a, cu√°l es su utilidad y estar√° en capacidad de identificar canales potenciales de comunicaci√≥n en los que se puedan aplicar t√©cnicas de esteganograf√≠a.

Palabras Clave
Esteganograf√≠a, criptograf√≠a, confidencialidad, malware, comunicaci√≥n

Programando en python desde el 2008. Todav√≠a prefiero matplotlib para los gr√°ficos, pero pandas para la manipulaci√≥n de datos, y por supuesto, de jupyter notebooks.

Title: Presentaciones y encuestas interactivas en jupyter notebooks y RISE
Description: Soy un fan de jupyter notebooks y la librer√≠a RISE desde el 2015, y siempre que me toca realizar un curso o presentaci√≥n con algo de c√≥digo los utilizo para hacer que el c√≥digo pueda tomar vida realmente. En esta charla, dar√© algunos consejos para sacar el m√°ximo provecho de la combinaci√≥n de jupyter notebook con RISE, y de c√≥mo hacer las presentaciones a√∫n m√°s interactivas, para un curso o una charla. Adem√°s, hace alg√∫n tiempo trat√© de realizar una encuesta en tiempo real durante una presentaci√≥n, pero no encontr√© en internet un tutorial o ayuda sobre c√≥mo hacerlo. As√≠ que me lanc√© a realizar algunos experimentos y encontr√© tres alternativas simples que me gustar√≠a compartir (y probar) en la audiencia, y que resumen el conocimiento ganado en varios d√≠as de experimentaci√≥n. En resumen: una charla para aprender a hacer charlas 100% interactivas con jupyter notebook.

Biography: I am a physicist from Universidad de los Andes interested in applying machine learning to different areas in both industry and academia. I am especially interested in the intersection between machine learning and physics.
Submission: Talk (40 minutes including Q&A) /  Charla (40 minutos incluyendo preguntas)
Title: Probabilistic Programming: Using Python to Simplify Statistical Inference
Description:
The rise of big data and machine learning has led to the development of models capable of making accurate predictions when trained with large amounts of data. However, machine learning models still struggle with a critical element: interpretability. In other words, it is difficult to tell why a machine learning model is making a particular prediction. 

As an alternative to pure machine learning models, statistical inference is a field that provides interpretable models that also quantify the uncertainty of the prediction. Statistical inference can sometimes be challenging to perform, so probabilistic programming is a paradigm that seeks to perform statistical analyses using the tools of computer science. Notably, these computer science tools simplify conducting inference by providing intuitive and efficient implementations of statistical methods.

This talk is about leveraging probabilistic programming to perform statistical inference in a simplified way using Python. In particular, I will cover how to use PyMC3 and Pyro in examples that illustrate the importance of probabilistic programming to solve challenges in the current data-driven world.
Tags: Data Sciece, Machine Learning, Scientific Computing
